derived a strong confirmation 
of my opinion with regard 
to the manner in which the 
air gains access to the <u>vacuum<\u>
of the Barometer: i.e. that it 
is by means of the glass 
& not of the mercury. While 
I quote the observation in 
support of my ideas upon 
the subject it will at the same time serve for a 
specimen of the skill &
exactness with which all the 
proceedings of the Society were 
regulated. The observation 
occurs in the directions given 
by the Secretary Hemmer for 
boiling the mercury in ther-
mometers - He thus expresses 
himself
